title: How important is writing history to people? - Quora

response.answer_text: Time is an historical phenomenon, a mentality, and a way of apprehending a changing world. It is the understanding of historical time, where time becomes concrete in the form of narratives and artifacts, which gives coherence to the individual events from the past. Understanding chronology is basic to visualizing the past and to making comparisons between historical eras and the present with regard to change and continuity. The widening gap between past and present often results in a new sensibility of time. Thinking about history and thinking historically are quite different things. Although most people think of history—and learn it—as a conglomeration of facts, dates, and key figures, for professional historians historical thinking is a way of knowing, a method for developing and understanding the relationships of peoples and events in the past. German historian of the late 19th century, Wilhelm Dilthey wrote, “We are historical beings first, before we are observers of history, and only because we are the former do we become the latter.” Dilthey's research interests revolved around questions of scientific methodology, historical evidence, and history's status as a science. He understood that the process of interpretive inquiry is not described in terms of an object or event of the past, but as a series of worldviews. [i] Academic scholarship seems particularly unable to depart from “present-mindedness” in writing histories filled with negative stereotypes relevant to contemporary paradigms and passing fancies of correctness. It is a bit unfair to hold persons from the past to modern standards of behavior and appropriate patterns of thought. The spans of time in human history are so vast when compared to the span of a lifetime and of recent history that it’s almost impossible to get a handle on it.  [i] Wilhelm Dilthey, Gesammelte Schriften, vol. VII, ed. B. Groethuysen (Stuttgart: B. Teubner, 1968), 277-278.

Studying history is important because it allows us to understand our past, which in turn allows us to understand our present. If we want to know how and why our world is the way it is today, we have to look to history for answers. People often say that “history repeats itself,” but if we study the successes and failures of the past, we may, ideally, be able to learn from our mistakes and avoid repeating them in the future. Studying history can provide us with insight into our cultures of origin as well as cultures with which we might be less familiar, thereby increasing cross-cultural awareness and understanding.
